title: 108_s1967
content: The Act titled "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" authorizes interest-bearing transaction accounts for all businesses. The Act "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" allows depository institutions to permit owners of certain accounts to make up to 24 transfers per month to another account in the same institution. The Act "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" allows depository institutions to offer transaction accounts unless prohibited by law. Amendments clarify restrictions on offering demand deposit accounts. The Act "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" allows institutions to offer transaction accounts unless prohibited by law. Amendments clarify restrictions on offering demand deposit accounts, with an effective date set for 2 years after enactment. Authorization of interest-bearing transaction accounts. Repeal of prohibition on payment of interest on demand deposits under various acts and joint rulemaking required within 2 years. The Secretary of the Treasury and Federal banking agencies must issue regulations allowing interest and dividends on transaction accounts at depository institutions within 2 years of this Act. The regulations will define the scope, types of accounts, and any limitations or restrictions. The regulations required by this subsection must include limitations, exceptions, or restrictions on authorization for interest and dividends on transaction accounts at depository institutions. Definitions for terms like "depository institution" and "transaction account" are provided in the Federal Reserve Act, while "Federal banking agency" is defined in the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. The amendments made by subsection (a) of the Federal Reserve Act and the Federal Deposit Insurance Act will become effective within 2 years of enactment or when final regulations are issued. SEC. 4. Payment of interest on reserves at Federal Reserve Banks. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at a Federal Reserve bank, with payments made quarterly at rates tied to short-term interest rates. The Board may issue regulations on earnings payments and distribution to these institutions. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at a Federal Reserve bank, with payments made quarterly at rates tied to short-term interest rates. Regulations are issued regarding the payment and distribution of earnings to these institutions. Responsibilities of depository institutions, Federal home loan banks, and the National Credit Union Administration Central Liquidity Facility are outlined for crediting and distributing earnings from balances maintained at a Federal reserve bank. The Federal Reserve Act allows depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at a Federal Reserve bank. Regulations are in place for the distribution of earnings to these institutions, including definitions for depository institutions. Additionally, authorization is given for pass-through reserves for member banks. The Federal Reserve Act authorizes pass-through reserves for member banks and includes technical and conforming amendments to certain sections of the Act. SEC. 5 amends the Federal Reserve Act to give the Federal Reserve Board more flexibility in setting reserve requirements. The ratio can now be not greater than 3 percent (including zero) and not less than 8 percent (including zero). SEC. 6 deals with the treatment of certain escrow accounts. In the case of an escrow account for real estate transactions, certain activities are excluded from being considered as interest payments under various laws, including absorbing expenses related to providing banking services for the account. The depository institution absorbs expenses and refrains from charging fees for providing banking services related to an escrow account. Any benefits to the account holder or beneficiary result from these actions.
